awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Detecting and Localizing Spectrum Offenders Using Crowdsourcing
awd_abstract_narration:
Software defined radio (SDR) is emerging as a key technology to satisfy rapidly increasing data rate demands on the nation's mobile wireless networks while ensuring coexistence with other spectrum users.  When SDRs are in the hands and pockets of average people, it will be easy for a selfish user to alter his device to transmit and receive data on unauthorized spectrum, or ignore priority rules, making the network less reliable for many other users.  Further, malware could cause an SDR to exhibit illegal spectrum use without the user's awareness.  The FCC has an enforcement bureau which detects interference via complaints and extensive manual investigation. The mechanisms used currently for locating spectrum offenders are time consuming, human-intensive, and expensive.  A violator's illegal spectrum use can be too temporary or too mobile to be detected and located using existing processes.  This project envisions a future where a crowdsourced and networked fleet of spectrum sensors deployed in homes, community and office buildings, on vehicles, and in cell phones will detect, identify, and locate illegal use of the spectrum across a wide areas and frequency bands. This project will investigate and test new privacy-preserving crowdsourcing methods to detect and locate spectrum offenders.  New tools to quickly find offenders will discourage users from illegal SDR activity, and enable recovery from spectrum-offending malware.  In short, these tools will ensure the efficient, reliable, and fair use of the spectrum for network operators, government and scientific purposes, and wireless users.  New course materials and demonstrations for use in public outreach will be developed on the topics of wireless communications, dynamic spectrum access, data mining, network security, and crowdsourcing.

There are several challenges the project will address in the development of  methods and tools to find spectrum offenders.  First, the project will enable localization of offenders via crowdsourced spectrum measurements that do not decode the transmitted data and thus preserve users? data and identity privacy.  Second, the crowd-sourced sensing strategy will implicitly adapt to the density of traffic and explicitly adapt to focus on suspicious activity.  Next, the sensing strategy will stay within an energy budget, and have incentive models to encourage participation, yet have sufficient spatial and temporal coverage to provide high statistical confidence in detecting illegal activity.  Finally, the developed methods will be evaluated using both simulation and extensive experiments, to quantify performance and provide a rich public data set for other researchers.

por.por_cntn:
The 4G/5G cellular and Wi-Fi networks providing all-pervasive network connectivity have become foundation of our modern life.  The new generation of these networks will need to use greater amount of radio frequency (RF) spectrum to provide increasingly higher speeds. Due to finite nature of RF spectrum, technologies that enable sharing of valuable spectrum among multiple services and users in order to maximize its utilization have been a major research area. Success of such sharing depends on availability of accurate data on use of spectrum in space and time and ensuring that the spectrum users do not exceed transmission frequencies and transmit power rights allocated to them. Our project aimed to explore research problems that underly these challenges.

Intellectual merit

Our research focused on following topics: (1) developing spectrum sensing data collection via crowdsourcing tools and techniques, (2) design of algorithms that  analyze such data  to detect transmitters and their violations of expected behavior, (3) design of algorithms for data driven spectrum management /sharing, and (4) application of modern security techniques such as  blockchain for secure sharing.

The project contributions were in the following areas:

(1)    We developed tools and software for using state-of-the-art high speed Software-Defined-Radio (SDR) platform to digitize RF signals from live 4G cellular,  Wi-Fi  and naval radar signal generator/transmitters situated in the lab setting and in an anechoic chamber in Bell Labs (MurrayHill, NJ) to build large, digital RF datasets.

(2)     We developed transmitter detection algorithms based on statistical signal processing and new machine learning (ML)/Deep Learning (DL) based techniques such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN).  We implemented these algorithms in state-of-the-art SDR based spectrum sensors and demonstrated live, real-time,  high-accuracy detection.

(3)    We designed a secure, blockchain based distributed coordination framework with non-repudiation, verification capabilities for Citizens Broadband Radio Services (CBRS) 3.5 GHz shared spectrum in USA involving multiple Spectrum Access Server (SAS)s that need to allocate channels to transmitters. We implemented this framework using open source tools to fully demonstrate its practical realization.

(4)    We developed spectrum enforcement techniques, leveraging directed measurements from cooperating collection of multi-location sensors controlled by a central server to detect violation of spectrum grants.

Broader Impact:

This grant provided opportunity to six Graduate Students from University of Utah and one student from Washington University in St. Louis to work in a premier industrial lab setting  to research problems at the cross-section of cutting-edge spectrum sharing technology and regulatory policy contextualized with industrial research. The grant supported three "Women in Engineering" minority students. The research conducted in this project provided foundations for two Ph.D and one Master’s thesis. The technologies and research outcomes of this project have been reported in several papers published in top tier conferences and are available for broader community use. The project also resulted in software systems that can serve as foundation for commercial products and has created intellectual property that led to a US Patent filing.  In short, our project has advanced knowledge base and software and system technologies that will contribute to the next generation of commercial and military wireless networks that will employ spectrum sharing.
